answers.answer: The main purpose of the Dopomoha initiative, a Commit Global solution, is to support refugees through two main solutions: "Law made simple," which helps citizens understand their rights and obligations, and "PTSD Help," a free assistant for managing Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD).
answers.bResponse: The main purpose of the Dopomoha initiative, a Commit Global solution, is to support refugees through two main solutions: "Law made simple," which helps citizens understand their rights and obligations, and "PTSD Help," a free assistant for managing Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD). For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/legal-status

answers.answer: Support services offered include housing, education, health, transportation, and call center assistance. Additionally, there are solutions designed to support refugees such as "Law made simple" to help citizens understand their rights and obligations, and "PTSD Help" as a free assistant for managing Post Traumatic Stress Disorder. Support is also available in other European countries like Poland, Moldova, Hungary, and The Slovak Republic, with hotlines and specific websites provided. Useful links for further support include UnAcoperis.ro, SprijinDeUrgenta.ro, WomenCenter, UkraineChildCancerHelp.ro, ConsiliereHIV.ro, and CineCeFace.ro.

answers.answer: The Romanian cities covered by the provided services include Brașov, Brăila, Constanța, Galați, Iași, Oradea, Suceava, Sibiu, Cluj-Napoca, and Timișoara.

answers.answer:
The main ways to enter Romania are by obtaining temporary protection, entering with a short-stay right, or as an asylum seeker.

Temporary protection is a special form of protection for people fleeing the war in Ukraine, with permits automatically valid until 03/04/2026 for existing beneficiaries.

Ukrainian nationals with a valid passport can enter with a short-stay right, allowing them to stay for up to 90 days.

Alternatively, individuals can enter as an asylum seeker. This status is granted from the moment one applies for asylum, either in writing or verbally, preventing deportation to the country of origin. If no documents can be presented upon entry, asylum must be applied for at the border. Asylum can also be applied for within Romania at a later point.
answers.bResponse:
The main ways to enter Romania are by obtaining temporary protection, entering with a short-stay right, or as an asylum seeker.

Temporary protection is a special form of protection for people fleeing the war in Ukraine, with permits automatically valid until 03/04/2026 for existing beneficiaries.

Ukrainian nationals with a valid passport can enter with a short-stay right, allowing them to stay for up to 90 days.

Alternatively, individuals can enter as an asylum seeker. This status is granted from the moment one applies for asylum, either in writing or verbally, preventing deportation to the country of origin. If no documents can be presented upon entry, asylum must be applied for at the border. Asylum can also be applied for within Romania at a later point. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/legal-status

answers.answer:
Yes, contact details are available for support in other European countries.

For Poland, the hotline is +48 47 721 75 75, with more information at www.ua.gov.pl and https://pomagamukrainie.gov.pl/.
For Moldova, the hotline is 0 8000 15 27, with more information at https://igm.gov.md/en/temporary-protection/.
For Hungary, the hotline is +36 1 463 9292, with more information at http://www.bmbah.hu/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&id=1736:2022-03-04-12-25-49&lang=hu.
For the Slovak Republic, the hotlines for Ukrainian-speakers are +421 513 816 111 and +421 259 765 111, with more information at https://www.mic.iom.sk/sk/novinky/760-informatsiya-ukrayina.html.
answers.bResponse:

answers.answer: One can provide feedback or report mistakes, inconsistencies, or omissions by writing an e-mail to dopomoha@code4.ro.

answers.answer: Dopomoha is a Commit Global solution. A partnership was also made with Access for the "Law made simple" and "PTSD Help" solutions, which are designed to support refugees.

answers.answer: Ukrainian nationals who present a valid passport at the border crossing can stay in Romania for up to 90 days under a short-stay right.
